advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... The 6800 will never win any beauty prizes. It is like the Model 'T' and the DC-3, not pretty but beautiful in function. It is simple, easy to use and maintain and does its job in the most reliable and economical way possible. What more could you want?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here are the 20 questions :-)<br><font color="#666666"> If you're looking for your first home computer, may we make a suggestion.<br> Tear out this page.<br> And ask these questions of every computer you look at.<br> 1) Is the basic price reason­able, say under £180?<br> 2) Does it work with a monitor as well as with an ordinary UHF TV?<br> 3) Does it include a basic training manual that doesn't require a science degree to understand?<br> 4) Does it have colour?<br> 5) And sound?<br> 6) Does it take cassettes?<br> 7) And cartridges?<br> 8) And can you operate them with joysticks working directly off the basic unit?<br> 9) Does it have a profes­sional quality keyboard that's guaranteed for twenty million de­pressions (and no headaches)?<br> 10) Does it have colour graphics that are capable of producing detailed pictures?<br> 11) Is the case robust enough to stand up to the kids?<br> ­12) Does it use a standard language that's not a million, miles away from English?<br> 13) Is there an expanding range of high quality sofrware available from the makers?<br> 14) Does the software in­clude educational programs for adults as well as the very young?<br> 15) And is there sofrware sophisticated enough to satisfy the experts?<br> 16) Does it use the most up to date technology, for instance the 6809E microprocessor?<br> 17) Will it drive a standard printer directly from the basic unit?<br> 18) Is it made in the UK?<br> 19) And for the basic price will I get an easily accessible, yet large memory of at least 32K?<br> 20) Or willI have to add lots of extras (and lots of money for that much?<br> After you've finished pester­ing every computer salesman in sight, compare your answers to these, Courtesy of the Dragon 32 (this is,after all, an ad for the Dragon)<br> Questions 1-19. Yes,yes,yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes and yes.<br> Question 20. No.<br> If you're thinking that that's a lot of computer for the money. you'd be right.<br> However, when you come to read the handbook you'll soon realise that somethings missing. The jargon usually asso­ciated with computers.<br> You see every part of the Dragon has been carefully designed to be easily under­stood,even by total beginners. Yet it has all the features an expert could want Just ask it. </font> </blockquote>

computer.description:
Little is known about this system, please help !
From Zahoor Iqbal Awan: I have used this system for 2+ years following configuration: Model System V - 100 Memory 8+8 mb Octart (Serial Ports) Boards x 2 Wyse Mono Terminals/Console 20+100 mb Harddisk (Bulky about 3~4kg) 20mb Tape Drive Large Floppy Drive Front Lock (Power system) Wyse Terminal Keyboard
- Had to boot cromix bootstrap first and then on to AT&T Unix system V earlier releases. - Used Informix for rdbms
computer.graphics: Unknown (optional high resolution card and optional Video Digitizing and imaging)
computer.keyboard: Full stroke keyboard with numeric keypad and function keys
computer.name: System V
